awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Correlated Motions in Protein Allostery
awd_abstract_narration:
Enzymatic activity is tightly regulated so that cellular resources are not wasted by the production of unnecessary components. Allostery is a common mechanism of enzyme regulation that involves sensing whether a modulator is bound at a site distinct from the site of catalysis. The information that the modulator is present must be transmitted through correlated motions to the active site, where depending on the function of the modulator, catalytic activity is either stimulated or inhibited. The goal of this project is to understand the correlated motions that give rise to protein allostery and relate them to protein sequence. To do this, the project will take an unprecedented approach that interfaces advanced X-ray scattering methods with complementary techniques, such as single-particle cryo-electron microscopy, and computational bioinformatics. An integral part of this project is to develop a modern structural biology course that incorporates active learning techniques to equip students with the technical knowledge needed to tackle compelling, interdisciplinary problems of the future. A career-focused seminar series will also be developed to educate STEM undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs to navigate their career paths and develop creative uses of their education.

An ideal family of enzymes for this study is the ribonucleotide reductase family, which performs a key reaction for all DNA-based life. Because of its importance in central metabolism, these enzymes have evolved multiple levels of complex allostery. To understand how enzyme activity is regulated, single-particle methods will be used to probe correlated motions within equilibrium states defined by small-angle X-ray scattering. Evolutionary correlations of the protein sequences will be determined by statistical methods and tested for significance by diffuse X-ray scattering. Finally, ancestral sequence reconstruction methods will be applied to understand how such allosteric mechanisms emerge and evolve.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes for CAREER: Correlated Motions in Protein Allostery (MCB-1942668)

Proteins are giant molecules that carry out the countless chemical reactions that allow life to exist. This project aimed to understand how proteins appear to breathe and move in order to carry out these functions, with a special focus on a family of proteins called ribonucleotide reductases (RNRs). These proteins are essential for DNA replication and repair and have been used by all living organisms—and even viruses—throughout billions of years of evolution. Our goal was to understand how these proteins use “allostery”—a mechanism that requires protein motion—to regulate their activity, much in the same way that a thermostat maintains a room’s temperature.

To do this, we used a combination of advanced tools from structural biology, bioinformatics, and molecular evolution. In particular, we employed cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), a powerful technique that allows us to visualize protein structures at near-atomic resolution, even as they shift and move. We also used X-ray scattering techniques and a range of computational methods to analyze large families of protein sequences and reconstruct ancestral forms of proteins.

One of the most exciting outcomes of this project was capturing proteins in motion as they carry out their work. Using cryo-EM, we visualized an RNR protein under physiological conditions and captured it in multiple stages of its catalytic cycle. We developed a new computational approach to compare “conformational landscapes” across datasets. Instead of simply averaging the observed structures, our method maps how the positions of individual protein components change before, during, and after a reaction. We discovered that this protein is constantly dancing, moving between many different shapes—even when no reaction is taking place—and that it samples a different distribution of these shapes when all of the necessary components of the reaction are in place. These findings offer a window into how proteins use motion to regulate chemical activity.

A second major area of the project explored how allosteric regulation evolves. Through bioinformatic analyses, we traced the evolutionary history of the RNR family and identified a previously unknown group of RNRs that appear to represent a missing evolutionary link between oxygen-dependent and oxygen-independent forms. Remarkably, this evolutionary bridge suggests that life may have adapted to the presence of oxygen on the planet earlier than previously thought.

Several software tools were developed as part of this project and are now freely available to the scientific community. One of these tools, called Miffi, uses machine learning to automatically filter out poor-quality cryo-EM images, improving the accuracy of structural studies. A set of Python scripts enables construction and comparison of physically interpretable conformational landscapes from cryo-EM data. Another tool, called REGALS, is used for unmixing signals in small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) data in an unbiased manner. These resources are expected to benefit a broad range of researchers.

Beyond research, this project had a major impact on education by providing interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students. A key component of this project was the development of a graduate-level course in modern structural biology that equips students with both a theoretical understanding of the physics behind structural techniques and practical experience in cryo-EM, X-ray crystallography, and SAXS. Within the first two years of this award, the course achieved a perfect rating. Students especially enjoyed the 12 hands-on activities covering a comprehensive range of topics, from crystallizing proteins and collecting data at a major synchrotron facility to reconstructing cryo-EM maps using cloud-based GPU computing. Through active learning, students gained tangible research skills and developed a long-term interest in structural biology.

Impact: This project has advanced our understanding of how protein motions are tied to function, how regulatory mechanisms change through evolution, and how to harness modern tools to study dynamic protein behavior. It has contributed new methods, concepts, and training opportunities that will have a lasting impact on structural biology and the broader STEM workforce. Our evolutionary studies provide a molecular-level view of how life may have adapted to major environmental changes—such as the rise of oxygen on early Earth—shedding light on how proteins evolve new functions.
